10.77.text:
In some countries, bill of rights are venerated
as repositories of those values that are held

16.10.text:
to be most precious.
In the United Kingdom, in contrast, the Human

20.92.text:
Rights Act - the closest thing we have to
a bill of rights in the modern sense - has

25.75.text:
been a source of bitter contention ever since
its enactment.

30.79.text:
Against this background, the Conservative
Party said in its election manifesto that

34.48.text:
it would repeal the Act and replace it with
a British Bill of Rights.

39.55.text:
In this presentation, I will attempt to answer
three key questions that these proposals invite.

45.25.text:
First, what are the perceived problems with
the Act?

48.94.text:
Second, how might a Bill of Rights be different?
And, third, what constitutional obstacles

55.08.text:
might get in the way of the implementation
of the Government's human-rights policy?

62.17.text:
The Human Rights Act was passed in 1998 and
came into force in 2000, its aim was to give

67.95.text:
greater effect in domestic law to the European
Convention on Human Rights.

73.89.text:
The UK had been a party to the Convention
since the 1950s, but until the entry into

78.43.text:
force of the Human Rights Act it was often
impossible for individuals to enforce their

83.16.text:
Convention rights in domestic courts.
The only alternative was to seek redress before

89.35.text:
the Court of Human Rights in Strasbourg - a
costly and time-consuming option that was

94.32.text:
by no means practically open to everyone.
The Act is not, therefore, a domestic bill

100.12.text:
of rights in the usual sense. Instead it is
an instrument that gives certain effects in

105.13.text:
national law to human-rights standards that
are anyway binding upon the UK internationally.

112.07.text:
The Act does this by:
obliging public authorities to act in accordance

115.81.text:
with the Convention rights;
directing the courts to interpret legislation

120.59.text:
compatibly with those rights where possible;
and allowing courts to issue declarations

125.96.text:
of incompatibility when legislation cannot
be so interpreted.

131.36.text:
The Act does not, however, allow courts to
strike down incompatible Acts of the UK Parliament.

137.11.text:
In this way, parliamentary sovereignty - according
to which the powers of the UK Parliament are

142.47.text:
legally unlimited - is preserved.
It may seem puzzling, then, that judges are

149.47.text:
considered (by some) to have too much power
under the Act.

153.35.text:
After all, Parliament - and so politicians,
not judges - retains the final word.

159.65.text:
However, the position is not quite this straightforward.
Although, in domestic-legal theory, Parliament

167.35.text:
still does have the final say - it can, if
it wishes, reverse a judicial attempt to read

174.03.text:
domestic legislation compatibly with Convention
rights, or ignore a declaration of incompatibility

179.56.text:
- its capacity actually to do these things
is limited.

185.71.text:
Notwithstanding that Parliament is sovereign
as a matter of domestic law, the Convention

190.10.text:
is binding upon the UK as a state in international
law.

195.18.text:
This means, among other things, that the UK
is legally obliged to secure the Convention

200.01.text:
rights to everyone within its jurisdiction,
and to abide by the Strasbourg Court's rulings.

207.26.text:
For some politicians, this is unpalatable,
both because the judges who, in effect, have

212.90.text:
the final word are European rather than British,
and because it is a court (rather than Parliament)

219.43.text:
that has that final word.
And so, for all that it is a deft constitutional

225.19.text:
measure, the Human Rights Act secures a degree
of lock-in to a pan-European judicial system

232.28.text:
that some politicians find unacceptable.
What, then, can be done by those - including

239.33.text:
the present Government - who take that view?
The enactment of a British Bill of Rights

244.70.text:
has long been held out as a panacea, the implication
being that British rather than European rights

251.00.text:
will be protected, and that domestic not European
judges will be in the driving seat.

256.77.text:
Indeed, this is precisely what the Government
appears to envisage.

261.66.text:
Its manifesto says that the proposed Bill
of Rights "will break the link" between British

266.41.text:
courts and the Strasbourg Court, and that
the UK Supreme Court will become the the "ultimate

271.92.text:
arbiter of human rights matters" in this country.
The manifesto also implies that the Bill of

278.25.text:
Rights may protect a narrower range of rights
than the Convention does, and that some rights

283.79.text:
will be subject to heavier qualifications
than at present, to enable competing public

288.67.text:
interests more readily to prevail.
A policy paper published by the Conservative

294.83.text:
Party in 2014 went further still, suggesting
that the judgments of the Strasbourg Court

301.02.text:
should be considered merely advisory, rather
than legally binding on the UK.

306.81.text:
So: can any of these things actually be done?
Whether the political will can be mustered

313.57.text:
is a question for others to analyse.
But what of the legal position?

319.09.text:
If - as it is generally still considered to
be - the UK Parliament is sovereign, it can

324.49.text:
ultimately do whatever a majority of its members
collectively wishes. Parliament is thus legally

330.56.text:
free to design whatever human-rights system
it wants, or to do away with human-rights

335.94.text:
legislation altogether.
But any analysis that relied upon such arguments

342.16.text:
would be grossly na�ve.
For two reasons, the position is more complex.

348.52.text:
The first of those reasons is implicit in
what I said earlier.

352.17.text:
It is that for as long as the UK remains a
party to the European Convention, Parliament

358.00.text:
- for all that it is sovereign - will not
have the luxury of legislating upon a blank

363.32.text:
legal canvas.
Of course, withdrawal from the Convention

367.85.text:
is not as unthinkable as it once was. Indeed,
the Conservatives' 2014 policy paper acknowledged

375.30.text:
that the changes it proposed might eventually
precipitate Britain's exit from the Convention

380.53.text:
regime.
But this surely remains unlikely, at least

384.78.text:
in the short term.
For the time being, therefore, the Convention

388.90.text:
will remain a constraining force.
This is not to suggest that the Convention

394.46.text:
requires the Human Rights Act (although it
does stipulate that national law must somehow

399.81.text:
supply effective remedies for breaches of
Convention rights).

403.25.text:
After all, the UK was a party to the Convention
for several decades prior to the inception

409.45.text:
of the Act.
Moreover, most States that are parties to

413.42.text:
the Convention do not possess national legislative
instruments that resemble the Human Rights

418.27.text:
Act - in most such States, national constitutions
and bill of rights, not the European Convention,

426.17.text:
form the focal point of human-rights adjudication.
Nevertheless, while the Convention does not

433.09.text:
prescribe domestic incorporation through something
like the Human Rights Act, an alignment between

439.13.text:
Convention rights and national law is called
for.

443.46.text:
The central obligation imposed by the Convention
upon States is not to permit aggrieved individuals

449.37.text:
to litigate in Strasbourg: it is to ensure
that national law and practice are consistent

454.46.text:
with the Convention rights in the first place.
To suggest, therefore, that the UK's human-rights

461.10.text:
regime can exist in glorious isolation from
- and be significantly misaligned with - the

466.67.text:
Convention is nonsensical.
Indeed, it is legally illiterate to imply

472.82.text:
that Strasbourg can be legislated out of the
picture by a domestic statute that has no

478.25.text:
purchase upon the UK's international legal
obligations.

484.54.text:
A second constitutional obstacle in the path
of the Government's proposals is devolution.

488.70.text:
Once again, as a matter of strict legal analysis,
the UK Parliament can do as it wishes.

496.33.text:
But just as the application of a wider lens
reveals that its freedom of action is constrained

500.94.text:
from above by international law, so its latitude
is also limited by the devolved nature of

507.82.text:
the UK's contemporary constitutional arrangements.
A fundamental aspect of those arrangements

514.60.text:
is a constitutional convention - in the sense
of an established and expected constitutional

519.14.text:
practice - known as the Sewel Convention.
This provides that although the UK Parliament

525.53.text:
has relinquished no legal authority, it will
resist exercising that authority in certain

531.89.text:
ways.
In particular, says the Sewel Convention,

535.66.text:
the UK Parliament will not normally legislate:
on matters with which the devolved legislatures

541.72.text:
can deal themselves,
or in a way that would alter those bodies'

546.84.text:
powers,
unless they consent to such Westminster legislation.

553.90.text:
In this way, the legal theory of parliamentary
sovereignty gives way to a system in which

558.99.text:
power is effectively divided between London,
on the one hand, and Belfast, Cardiff and

564.93.text:
Edinburgh on the other.
How, then, does this affect the capacity of

570.37.text:
the UK Government and Parliament to implement
changes to human-rights law, bearing in mind

576.09.text:
that some of the devolved governments have
already signalled strong opposition to such

581.31.text:
changes?
The Human Rights Act itself is something that

585.69.text:
only the UK Parliament can amend or repeal.
And if it were to be amended or repealed,

590.93.text:
this would not affect the devolved legislatures'
powers, since they would remain bound by the

595.63.text:
devolution legislation to respect the European
Convention on Human Rights.

600.96.text:
It follows that repeal of the Human Rights
Act against the devolved legislatures' wishes

605.96.text:
would disclose no breach of the Sewel Convention
itself.

609.76.text:
However, the enactment of a British Bill of
Rights would be a different matter.

614.58.text:
Human-rights law, as distinct from the Human
Rights Act, is not reserved solely to the

620.46.text:
competence of the UK Parliament.
And this means that the enactment of a Bill

624.64.text:
of Rights against the wishes of the devolved
legislatures would imply a breach of the Sewel

630.41.text:
Convention.
This, in turn, means that such legislation

633.51.text:
would be unconstitutional.
It does not follow that it would be unlawful.

639.02.text:
Nor does it follow that a court could stop
this from happening.

642.49.text:
But what does follow is that the unilateral
imposition of a new Bill of Rights by Westminster

647.51.text:
would, in the first place, be highly unlikely.
To the extent that they have any binding effect,

654.30.text:
constitutional conventions acquire it from
the strength of the constitutional principle

658.52.text:
which they institutionalise,
and the corresponding political difficulties

662.84.text:
that would attend disregard of that principle.
Given the present fragility of the Union,

669.67.text:
and given that the Sewel convention enshrines
the need for the devolved nations' autonomy

674.38.text:
to be be respected,
it would be a brave Government that sought

677.57.text:
to press ahead with human-rights changes in
the face of opposition from the devolved nations

683.36.text:
and in a manner that would therefore be unconstitutional.
The upshot, then, is that while the proposed

690.54.text:
changes to human rights law are not impossible,
their adoption is rendered much more difficult

695.92.text:
by the multi-layered nature of the UK's modern
constitution.

700.93.text:
No longer is it the case that a single, sovereign
Parliament in Westminster calls all the shots.

707.26.text:
Instead, it sits within a network of sub-
and supra-national constitutional relationships

713.64.text:
that necessarily condition the exercise of
its authority, even if none of them represents

718.51.text:
a straightforward challenge to its legal sovereignty.
The bottom line, then, is that unless the

725.18.text:
Government can secure devolved buy-in to its
proposals, and unless it seeks to resile from

730.77.text:
the European Convention on Human Rights, its
room for manoeuvre is very limited indeed.

737.23.text:
Bold promises of change have been made. But
whether they can be delivered in a manner

742.36.text:
that is legally coherent and constitutionally
feasible is a different matter entirely.
